newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Spain maize imports feature on EU grain panel agenda.
newsitem.headline: Spain maize imports feature on EU grain panel agenda.

text.p: Preferential maize imports into Spain will again be the focus at a meeting of the European Union's cereals management committee on Thursday, as all other 1996/97 grain tenders have ended, EU officials said.
Last week the EU approved the import of 5,500 tonnes of maize into Spain with a maximum tariff reduction of 61.17 ecus a tonne.

The maize import quota, which compensates U.S. exporters for losses after Spain aligned its tariffs to higher EU levels on joining the bloc in 1986, was raised by 300,000 tonnes to 800,000 tonnes last month.
The grain panel is also due to vote on a proposal requiring proof of arrival for grain shipments of more than 1,500 tonnes benefiting from differentiated export refunds.
Officials said that the change to regulation 1501/95 would mainly affect sales to Morocco, Algeria and other North African countries for which special refund rates are set.
"The aim is to improve controls to ensure the grain is delivered to the specified destinations," one source said.
Vessels carrying less than 1,500 tonnes of grain will continue to have to show proof of arrival.
The committee will discuss the grain needs of the Canary Islands, Madeira and the Azores in 1997/98 (July/June), the officials added.
Grain shipments to these remote Spanish and Portuguese islands benefit from EU export refunds.
The needs of French overseas departments, such as Martinique and Reunion, will be discussed at a later date.
A vote is also expected on Thursday on proposals to change rules for aid payments to farmers growing cereals and oilseeds on set-aside land for industrial uses.
"The aim is to ensure that the aid is being properly used," said one source.
The changes, which concern Regulation 334/93, require member states to set representative cereals and oilseed yields each year. Farmers would be penalised if they failed to achieve the yields.
The representative yields could be set for each farm, district, region or country.
High erucic acid oilseed varieties would be excluded from the new rules.
